Complete Blood Count (CBC): Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), anemia (low red blood cell count), and leukopenia (low white blood cell count) due to bone marrow suppression.
Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, Bilirubi: Elevated levels indicating hepatotoxicity or liver dysfunction.
Renal Function Tests (Creatinine, BUN): Potentially elevated levels due to nephrotoxicity or concurrent use with other nephrotoxic drugs.
Lipid Profile (Cholesterol, Triglyceride: Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides, increasing cardiovascular risk.
Serum Electrolytes (Potassium, Magnesium: Potential imbalances, such as hyperkalemia (high potassium) or hypomagnesemia (low magnesium).
C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Reduced levels due to suppression of immune responses, though variable depending on the underlying condition.
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Reduced levels due to suppression of inflammation.
Trough Sirolimus Levels: Abnormal therapeutic drug levels (too high or too low), affecting efficacy or toxicity.
Urinalysis: Proteinuria or hematuria in cases of renal dysfunction.
Serum Glucose: Hyperglycemia due to metabolic side effects, particularly in patients at risk for diabetes.
Serum LDH: Elevated levels in cases of tissue damage or hemolysis.
Bone Marrow Biopsy: May show hypocellularity in cases of significant cytopenias.
Serum Immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM): Reduced levels due to immunosuppressive effects on B-cell function.
Vitamin D and Calcium: Low levels associated with impaired bone metabolism and increased fracture risk.
Parathyroid Hormone (PTH): Elevated levels in cases of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to renal involvement.
Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs): Abnormal results if pulmonary toxicity or pneumonitis occurs.
